zone.line: Chapter VI
My chamber was in a retired part of
the house, and looked upon the garden
so that no sound of the other inhabitants
could reach it; and here in perfect
solitude I wept for several hours.
When a servant came to ask me if I
would take food I leant learnt from
him that my father had returned, and
was apparently well and this relieved me
from a load of anxiety, yet I did not
cease to weep bitterly. As first, as the
memory of former happiness contrasted
to my present despair came across me,
I gave relief to the oppression of heart
that I felt by sighs ^words, and groans, and
heart rending sighs: but nature
became wearied, and this more violent
grief gave place to a passionate but
a silent ^mute flood of tears: my whole soul
di seemed to dissolve them. I did
not wring my hands, or tear my hair,
or utter wild exclamations, but as
Boccacio describes the intense and quiet
